postsData.content:
We found $5M in hidden revenue sitting in a cruise company's database...

And they had no idea it was there.

Here's what we discovered:

-- 27,000 leads were collecting dust in their CRM... 16,000 of them viable ones
-- Each booking was worth $3,500 on average
-- They were spending $16,800/year on flyers that brought in just 2 clients

The problem?

They were chasing new leads while ignoring a goldmine of existing ones.

So we pitched an AI system that:

-- Automatically reactivated old leads
-- Responded instantly to inquiries
-- Maintained consistent follow-up
-- Required zero additional staff

The results?

Even converting just 5% of those old leads would generate $5M in new bookings.

And the cost?

Less than what they were spending on flyers.

Here's the truth:

Most businesses are sitting on a fortune in untapped opportunities.

They just need the right tools to unlock it.

Sad thing is, this company never moved forward with our offer. Not everyone is ready for the AI revolution.

What hidden revenue is your business missing? If you had this opportunity, would you seize it?

postsData.content:
Vulnerability has often been seen as a weakness and for a long time, I believed that too. 

But as I grew in leadership, I learnt that vulnerability isn‚Äôt a flaw, it‚Äôs a strength.

When embraced, vulnerability heals us and when used in leadership, it can heal others too.

It‚Äôs not about sharing every personal detail or flaw; it‚Äôs about showing up authentically, acknowledging challenges and admitting when we don‚Äôt have all the answers. By being real, we invite others to do the same.

Leaders who embrace vulnerability create trust, break down barriers and build a culture where growth and healing happen. It‚Äôs in this space that we stop pretending everything‚Äôs perfect, learn from our mistakes and foster deeper connections.

By talking openly about our struggles, we normalise seeking help, reducing the stigma around mental health at work.

Vulnerability shifts the conversation, making it a strength, not a weakness and gives others the courage to do the same.

Let‚Äôs embrace vulnerability. It heals, connects and creates a workplace where growth can thrive.

comments.commentText: Authentic leadership isn‚Äôt about having all the answers, it‚Äôs about creating space for honest conversations.

Nerea Arregui Exposito Your perspective is thought-provoking, Let's Connect.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Embracing vulnerability fosters genuine connections and builds a culture of trust and growth. Let‚Äôs lead with authenticity! üåü

Are you tracking success‚Äîor just looking at past results? 

Most businesses rely on lag indicators‚Äîmetrics that tell you what already happened.

But by the time you see a problem, it‚Äôs too late to fix it.

Benjamin faced this exact challenge‚Äîuntil he shifted his focus to lead indicators, which predict future performance and allow for proactive adjustments.

ùóüùó≤ùóÆùó± ùóúùóªùó±ùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùóºùóøùòÄ (Predictive Metrics):
 Sales Pipeline Health: Instead of just tracking closed deals, Benjamin monitored the number of high-quality leads entering the pipeline.
 Customer Engagement Rate: Instead of focusing on past revenue, he analyzed how often customers interacted with content, webinars, and trials.
 Employee Productivity Trends: Instead of waiting for quarterly performance reviews, he tracked weekly task completion rates to spot inefficiencies early.

ùóüùóÆùó¥ ùóúùóªùó±ùó∂ùó∞ùóÆùòÅùóºùóøùòÄ (Historical Metrics):
 Revenue Reports: Tells you what‚Äôs already been earned but doesn‚Äôt indicate future sales trends.
 Customer Churn Rate: Shows how many customers you lost but doesn‚Äôt help prevent attrition in real-time.
 Employee Turnover Rate: Highlights past resignations but doesn‚Äôt flag disengagement before it happens.

 The key to success? Balance both.

 Lead indicators drive proactive decisions. Lag indicators confirm if your strategy worked.

In our world‚Ä¶

postsData.content:
Great analysis from Jeffrey Grabow of EY on the state of venture capital. The Q4 2024 data shows a significant resurgence, with total investments reaching $62.2 billion‚Äîa 57% increase from the previous quarter and the highest since Q1 2022.

 AI's Dominance ‚Äì AI continues to be the top investment priority, with four major AI deals accounting for $26.6 billion in Q4 2024, over 60% of total VC investments last quarter.

 Sector Focus: IT Takes the Lead ‚Äì In 2024, IT captured nearly half of all VC investments, significantly outpacing other sectors. Funding for IT was more than twice that of health and life sciences, five times greater than consumer goods and services, and almost ten times higher than energy. This heavy concentration of capital in AI and emerging technologies underscores investor priorities.

 Fewer Deals, Larger Investments ‚Äì While total VC funding is rising, the number of deals has dropped significantly, falling below 10,000 for the first time since 2012. This signals a shift in investor priorities, with capital concentrating on AI and emerging technologies, making it more challenging for legacy companies to secure funding. Startups should focus on innovation and differentiation to stand out in this competitive landscape.

 Geographic Trends ‚Äì The San Francisco Bay Area, New York, and Boston continue to dominate in VC funding, but emerging tech hubs like Austin, Miami, and Los Angeles are seeing increased investor attention. Startups in these regions should leverage local ecosystem advantages.

 VC Market Surges, But Deals Decline ‚Äì Venture capital investment soared to over $180 billion in 2024, marking a 27% increase from 2023. However, despite this growth, the number of deals dropped below 10,000 for the first time since 2012. This trend suggests that investors are becoming more selective, concentrating capital into fewer, high-potential startups‚Äîespecially in AI and emerging technologies. For founders, this means that while funding is available, competition is tougher than ever, making differentiation and strong business fundamentals essential.

Read the full EY report here:

What‚Äôs your take on these trends? How is your startup adapting to this evolving VC landscape?
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights! The shift towards fewer deals and AI dominance emphasizes the need for startups to innovate and stand out. How is your team adapting?

postsData.content:
I was recently catching up with my friend, who‚Äôs an expat in Taiwan and has been trying to start her own startup in the country. 

She said Taiwanese companies are often too risk averse and the country needs to become more entrepreneurial. (Note: I‚Äôm not sure how much of that is true - it‚Äôs one person‚Äôs opinion. Also my understanding is that Taiwan is the ‚ÄúIsrael of Asia‚Äù, with many strong high-tech SMB ventures..)

I joked to her that Korea has an opposite problem. Koreans - the ‚ÄúItalians of Asia‚Äù - are taking too much risk, as it seems everyone and their mother are buying meme coins these days :)

Jokes aside - some countries or companies (especially big, stable companies) are more risk averse, while their leaders often try to imbue more sense of risk-taking and entrepreneurship.

I think it comes down to a simple fact - if the potential downside of risk taking is bigger than the potential upside, people become risk averse. For example, if a company has a surefire cash cow business that‚Äôs printing money, how many teams would want to try launching a new project at the risk of potentially hurting the cash cow business?

That is, unless they have a full endorsement from the management that any short-term negative implications ("the downside") will be tolerated, while the team will participate in any potential upside.

If leaders want their organizations to become more risk-taking, they should think about how to reduce the potential downside and increase the potential upside for their risk-taking squad.

comments.commentText: I didn‚Äôt know Korea was changing into risk takers - that is encouraging. Perhaps it‚Äôs because of the general economic success of the last couple decades?
This is so Taiwan. The culture does not encourage taking risks or failure. Everyone feels their product must be perfect before launching anything. Not sure how to change that!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Balancing risk and reward is crucial for fostering innovation. Leaders must create an environment where teams feel empowered to take calculated risks! üöÄ

During my keynote at Berkeley Lab last month, something shifted in the room when we explored a simple but powerful question:

Instead of asking "Is this the right decision?"

Try asking "Is this safe to try?"

(H/T to Alexis Gonzales-Black for teaching me this reframe)

Why does this small change matter?

It moves us from:
‚Ä¢ Seeking perfection to enabling progress
‚Ä¢ Fearing failure to learning from outcomes
‚Ä¢ Analysis paralysis to thoughtful action
‚Ä¢ Binary thinking to exploring possibilities

One attendee captured it perfectly:
"Hard decisions can be navigated instead of paralyzing."

This is why I love decision engineering - it's not about eliminating uncertainty, it's about finding practical ways to move forward with clarity.

What decisions might feel different if you asked "Is this safe to try?"

comments.commentText: Great, thought-provoking reframe...from "right" to "safe." The question opened a plethora of new possibilities.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Shifting our mindset can unlock innovation and progress. Embracing safe to try truly enhances our decision-making process!

postsData.name:
Paul Lister
Paul Lister
postsData.content:
On the courses I run I sometimes hear that the Agile Manifesto doesn‚Äôt always define other practices and methodologies that are said to be ‚ÄòAgile‚Äô. And that is true. When it was created the people involved tried to take core commonalities from ideas like Scrum, XP, Kanban etc and create four values. They did this so they would be a useful guideline for others. But is there a way of writing a more ‚Äòcatch all‚Äô general manifesto.
Let‚Äôs think about it.
Individuals and Interactions over Processes and tools is basically saying let people make decisions and trust them to do so. Allowing them to pivot quickly rather than slowly due to a set workflow. Customer collaboration over Contract negotiation is doubling down on this point from a stakeholder context. Quick feedback mechanisms rather than a set menu. Working together rather than ordering. Responding to change rather than following a plan reinforces this even more with a subtext of ‚Äòwhat‚Äô is being made is more important than ‚Äòhow much‚Äô of it has been completed. And finally working software over extensive documentation which again dovetails into these other ideas by implying that it is better to make something and get early opinions on it rather than trying to specify it to the nth degree.
So I‚Äôd like to suggest a kind of ‚ÄòBig Agile‚Äô manifesto, that doesn‚Äôt change the original but lives around it in a macro way. Much like the first manifesto did for the myriad of ideas that had sprouted since the fifties:
‚Ä¢ Assumption over Investigation
‚Ä¢ Trust over Control
‚Ä¢ Listening over Directing
‚Ä¢ Outcome over Output
The added bonus of this is because it has distance from the Agile manifesto is that it can serve as a check for a process you are using that you think is Agile.
So let me know what you think about this more generalised set of values. Is it useful or not and is there something that I have missed ?
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! A Big Agile manifesto could indeed clarify the essence of Agile practices and enhance adaptability. Excited to see where this goes!

postsData.content:
Here's the basics of how to do your outreach...

Start with a solid list of the folks you want to build a relationship with. Because that's what it is about. Not constantly pitching people.

Reach out with thoughtful and strategic messaging to connect and engage.

In this example, your CTA is a Zoom call (everybody's online now so yippee for that!)

On that very 1st Zoom, don't pitch out of the gates. Be curious about them. Ask genuine questions about their business. Make sure the questions are designed to enlighten you on where you will be able to provide help.

Be sure to have a follow up next step and make that happen. This next step is all about continuing to build rapport and adding value. Part of your pipeline management process.

As you engage with more and more prospects, have a process to gather emails and get them into your distribution platform. Then nurture all of your connections with targeted content that is designed to help them in some way.

Remember, as you talk to prospects, 90%+ will be long term leads. You will not convert them right away. This is normal. So you must stay close to them and nurture while you are asking for the business.

Craft a master lead list that you are updating along the way. This keeps you focused on WHO is in your pipeline and what needs to happen to move people forward.

Want to get 1 on 1 with me? Text GIANTHELP to 650-459-2712

Wait! Don't forget to notice these people who are doing amazing work...

postsData.content:
8 outdated myths about workplace culture
(let's bust them)

Shout out to Foong N. for this carousel.

1/ Real "team players" join after-work drinks
The truth: Team spirit is built through collaboration, not social obligations.

2/ Hybrid teams can't perform at their best
The truth: People often do their best work without office distractions.

3/ Top talent eats, breathes and sleeps work
The truth: Ideas and innovation come from diverse interests.

4/ Think parental leave is "time off"?
The truth: It's 24/7 care. Physically and emotionally exhausting.

5/ Purpose-driven? Good luck with profits!
The truth: Mission-oriented greats outperform them all.

6/ The loudest voice has the best ideas
The truth: The quietest listeners have the most to say.

7/ Skills are everything
The truth: So is the right attitude, empathy, and respect.

8/ Free perks build the best culture
The truth: It's how we treat our people that builds culture.

I've seen these myths ruin great workplace cultures.
The secret to fixing it?

Focus on how and what we achieve at work.
Not outdated, rigid expectations.

What's the worst workplace myth you've heard?
_______

postsData.content:
If you provide some sort of service on LinkedIn; you‚Äôve probably done this:


Post after post of 5 tips to do X or 3 hacks for Y. You‚Äôre all about the ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù content. And honestly, it‚Äôs good stuff. People save it, like it, maybe even DM you with a thanks for this.

Your audience? The ones you‚Äôre trying to attract? They‚Äôre not just walking bundles of I need tips. They‚Äôre actual humans with feelings, frustrations, and emotional baggage that don‚Äôt magically go away after reading a checklist.

Let me paint you a picture

Say you‚Äôre a fitness coach. Sure, your audience wants tips on how to lose weight or build muscle, but you know what‚Äôs really keeping them up at night?

They‚Äôre staring at their reflection, feeling like they‚Äôve let themselves go.

They‚Äôre embarrassed to show up at the gym because they think everyone‚Äôs judging them.

They‚Äôre tired of being the friend who‚Äôs always on a diet but never sees results.

Where‚Äôs that content? The one that says, Hey, I see you. You‚Äôre frustrated, you‚Äôre exhausted, and it feels like nothing is working‚Äîbut here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs not too late to turn things around.

Or maybe you‚Äôre a business coach.

It‚Äôs not about how to increase revenue or organizing your team for success.
Your clients might secretly be spiraling because:

They feel like imposters, wondering how they even got here.

They‚Äôre burnt out but too scared to take a break because what if everything falls apart?

They‚Äôre terrified they‚Äôll fail and let their family down.

That‚Äôs the real stuff nobody talks about.

So, yeah, share the hacks. Share the tips. But mix it up. Call out the messy middle‚Äîthe frustrations, the fears, the sleepless nights.

Speak to their ultimate desires, too:
 Confidence.
 Freedom.
 Finally feeling at peace with where they are.

When you start creating content that hits both their minds AND their hearts? That‚Äôs when your brand becomes unforgettable.

Because tips and tricks are cool‚Ä¶ but showing people you truly understand them? That‚Äôs magic.

PS: Be truthful, how many tips and tricks do you share per week?

I build the best personal brands with content ‚ÄºÔ∏è Ready to stand out? Let's talk!

comments.commentText: Mix them up, this is why you should have a content calendar and strategy so everyday you won‚Äôt post the same kind of content.
Favour Commander Exactly. You'll be able to mix it well when you have a structured calendar.

When you speak to your audience's emotions, you are not creating lasting impact and healing wounds, you begin to create a tribe emotionally connected to you.

And isn't that all we need? A community that loves and trusts us because we care about solving their painful and secret problems?

When you stop seeing your audience as just numbers, you'll begin to care. And when you care, the default becomes speaking directly to both their minds and hearts.
Chidinma Eze that connection becomes so strong.
